awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Project: Carolina Cyber Defense Scholarship
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNCC) and North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NCAT) propose to continue and expand the Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship Program supported by the CyberCorps(R) Scholarship for Service (SFS) program. The project will prepare highly-qualified cybersecurity professionals for entry into the government workforce, and will have an immediate impact on the information assurance and forensics capabilities of the federal workforce by developing well-trained cybersecurity professionals. The project will support community college students at the Forsyth Tech Community College (FTCC) through early mentoring and advising activities before their transfer to either UNCC or NCAT through established 2+2 pathways. Further, the proposed collaboration will help NCAT obtain CAE-R designation in research and contribute towards graduating under-represented cybersecurity researchers at the PhD level.

This project involves students in cybersecurity research and hands-on activities guided by a large team of experienced faculty, with sixteen current research initiatives and active funding from government agencies and private corporations. The core expertise is focused on Secure Software Development; Secure Network Administration; Cyber intelligence and Analytics; and Cloud Security. The NSF supported Industry/University Collaborative Research Center on Configuration Analytics and Automation provides a rich environment where students work on cutting-edge cybersecurity challenges and integrate with classroom education, which has generated many innovations, including a U.S. patent awarded to a team of SFS students at UNC Charlotte. The proposed program is designed to provide students with a solid foundation of cybersecurity, exposure to real-world cybersecurity problems, and hands-on experiences through competitions so that upon graduation they are well-prepared to meet the challenges of defending the nation's critical infrastructure. NCAT is implementing a new Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) approach for teaching cybersecurity. POGIL is based on the process of guided inquiry - a learning cycle of exploration, concept invention and application based on carefully designed materials that students use to guide them to construct cybersecurity knowledge.

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits

The intellectual merits of the NSF SFS program are based on the program’s commitment to involve students in cybersecurity research and hand-on activities guided by a large team of experienced PIs. Our core expertise is focused in the following cybersecurity areas: Secure Software Development, Secure Network Administration, Cyber intelligence and Analytics, and Cloud Security with sixteen current research initiatives and active funding from government agencies and private corporations. The NSF supported Industry/University Collaborative Research Center on Configuration Analytics and Automation provides a rich environment where students can work on cutting-edge cybersecurity challenges and integrate with classroom learning.

Broader of Impacts

The Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship Program is committed to produce high quality cybersecurity professionals, to increasing the diversity of the cybersecurity workforce, and to increasing the diversity of elite cybersecurity researchers with a PhD degree. We are committed to outreach activities that will inspire more people to pursue careers in cybersecurity. One important step in this direction is to involve community colleges and provide new opportunities for students to become cybersecurity professionals and serve the county.

Summarize the Outcome

The Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship Program North Carolina A&T State University collaborated with Forsyth Community Technical College. This program supported twenty-six students that included one PhD student, twenty-two MS students, and three undergraduate students from Forsyth Community Technical College who received an associate degree then transferred to North Carolina A&T State University for the BS degree. This program supported diverse students. Most of them are minority and six of them are female. Twenty of them graduated with Computer Science (CS) MS degree, one received CS PhD degree and three of them received CS BS degree. Two of them will graduate with CS MS degree Spring 2024.

All NSF SFS recipients participated in cybersecurity research related projects. They completed the PhD dissertation, the MS thesis/project, or the BS project. Under faculty members’ supervision SFS recipients conducted research in areas of secure software engineering, information assurance, Web security, trustworthy cloud computing, machine learning, artificial intelligence, etc. All NSF SFS recipients attended the Cyber Corp. Symposium online/face to face in Washington DC every January. They also attended NSF Virtual job fair every Fall.  Some of them attended cybersecurity related conferences and presented their papers.

All NSF SFS recipients found Summer Internships. Most of them worked with the Federal government in the cybersecurity area. After NSF SFS recipients graduated and received the degrees most of them worked/have been working for federal government in cybersecurity areas, and some of them worked/have been working for state governments in cybersecurity areas.

We developed and offered eight Information Assurance and cybersecurity related courses. Two of them are undergraduate courses and six of them are graduate courses.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2023
Modified by: Huiming Anna Yu
